urn:contentItem:5J2R-B431-DY0W-43PK-00000-00Analysis of Current Stock Market; Discussion about Tesla in the Stock Market; Governor Rick Scott on His Success in Making Florida Business2014-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:32ZLexisNexisAnalysis of Current Stock Market; Discussion about Tesla in the Stock Market; Governor Rick Scott on His Success in Making Florida BusinessLanhamFULL TEXT

MELISA FRANCIS, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: We do have a big show today. We have two governors, both exclusive, Florida's Rick Scott, Mississippi's Phil Bryant, both on huge job pushes right now. Today's signature Wall Street throwdown features Charlie Gasparino and Chapwood Fund's Jared Levy. That's going to be great, fighting over whether something smells fishy in the Tesla bond deal being underwritten by Morgan Stanley. You might want to get some popcorn for that one. And of course, there is today's "Money Talker", the latest round in Icahn versus eBay. Because even when they say it's not it is always about money.

FRANCIS: New Fed chair Janet Yellen just wrapping up her testimony before the Senate banking committee. Let's check in with Scott Shellady on the floor of the CME. You know, one thing in particular caught my attention. She said the economic data, particularly consumer spending had softened since she testified before the House committee. That was just two weeks ago! Things have gotten worse in the past two weeks, does that make you nervous, Scott?

SCOTT SHELLADY, TREAN GROUP SENIOR V.P.: Well, you know what? It is not making me nervous because I think I've felt this way for two or three months now ever since the retailers gone to came in weak over Christmas. So, here is where we sit. We've got a Fed that is going to be trying to taper. And they're tapering because - not because the economy can handle it. We're actually in a soft patch right now. But they are going to taper because it is a failed economic policy. And if they stop the taper I think that also sends another bad signal and the market could actually tumble from there as well, because, though, that reads into the fact that maybe the Fed sees something that is worse than we actually think. So we're in a very precarious spot right now.

FRANCIS: So what do you think she should do?

SHELLADY: Well, this is what I think is going to happen. I think that we try to put Q.E. out of there to inflate our way out of this problem and get some growth. We didn't buy any growth.

FRANCIS: Right.

SHELLADY: Aim two and a half percent GDP, that didn't happen, and we definitely didn't get any inflation. So, what the Fed is going to have to start doing now is fight deflation. So, I think ultimately we're going to have to stimulate, but maybe not in the way that we've been doing up until now. Maybe interest on overnight reserves or some other way because this is not going to be the way to work. I think that ultimately you're going to watch what happened in Japan. And if we do have the deflation, deflation is the one thing that the Fed is really scared about.

FRANCIS: Yeah. So, meanwhile, against that backdrop, leave that markets board up right now, look at the S&P 500. It is trading at 1853.59. All- time intraday high, 1858. We're flirting with record territory here. So, why are we seeing such a move in the S&P if you're painting a precarious picture there?

SHELLADY: Right. I know, it is perverse, is it? And why do we see the ten-year yields rally at the same time?

FRANCIS: There you go.

SHELLADY: Well, this is what's going to be. This is the world we're in. We're going to see ten percent - we're going to put ten percent on the stocks by end of the year. Maybe even 15 percent because we're going to either stimulate in a different manner, or, the economy does finally catch up and justifies these asset prices where they are. But in either scenario I think we're going to add to stocks, just because I think ultimately I think it's going to be the stimulus. I don't think it's going to be the economy is not going to catch up. And number two is that the ten-year is telling me that we still have a lot to worry about. That's why it didn't, the ten-year didn't break when we saw the stocks rally last week and early this week. Now, the ten year are starting to rally and the yields are starting to break, and we are still rallying as far as the stock market goes. We are in trouble. We need to see bunches of good numbers. Boy, oh, boy, is this jobs number on Friday, next Friday, very important.

FRANCIS: Nice setup for us, Scott, thanks so much.

SHELLADY: Already.

FRANCIS: So, everyone is talking Tesla today. Shares hitting the brinks after wild week of gains. Auto makers planning a bond offering to raise $1.6 billion for its new battery factory. But here is where the controversy comes in. So, one of the banks that is backing the deal, Morgan Stanley just released a report with a huge price target raise that sent the stock soaring. Is there a conflict of interest in there? Get ready to rumble in today's Wall Street Throwdown. It is Chapwood Investments, Jared Levy, against our very own Charlie Gasparino.

FRANCIS: Oh, yeah. There you go. The whistle .

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Charlie.

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS: You've got to do that in my ear?

FRANCIS: Yes he did have to do that, he wanted to get your attention ahead of time and ensure that it was a fair fight. What do you think? You're the one Charlie Gasparino, you're one that sort of raised the issue. Isn't that convenient? They raised .

GASPARINO: Gambling here - Is it gambling?

FRANCIS: From 153 to 320.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: And then boom it's announced the next day that they're underwriting the convert deal.

GASPARINO: Well, the one of the - one of the .

FRANCIS: One of four.

GASPARINO: I mean this is so obvious it is not even worth debating. Anybody that says it is not obvious is crazy. And just doesn't know how Wall Street works. The bottom line is this, these Wall Street firm sells - somewhere ten years after we had a major settlement in terms of Wall Street allegedly cleaning up its sell-side research, separating, creating the alleged or the infamous Chinese Wall, making it more sturdy it is just as broken. This stuff goes on every day.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Jared, Charles has just called you crazy and said you don't know how Wall Street works, by the way.

GASPARINO: One other thing, we should put out.

FRANCIS: Just not to throw .

GASPARINO: One other thing we should put out - They didn't just like, you know, say Tesla is a good company.

FRANCIS: No, 153 to 320. I mean that's .

GASPARINO: They went insane.

FRANCIS: Jared, are you crazy?

JARED LEVY, CHAPWOOD FUND MANAGING PARTNER: OK, maybe a little bit. You know, I've been doing this for 20 years, right? And I think Charlie is giving way too much credit to the four analysts that maybe just graduated from Wharton over at Morgan Stanley. Like they're calling Goldman and JPMorgan, say, hey guys, guess what? First of all, we're going to issue debt and we're going to dilute the shares. Which normally sends stock lower by the way. Just to read .

GASPARINO: Convertible debt?

LEVY: Yeah. Convertible - whatever your .

GASPARINO: It's going to convert.

LEVY: Issue debt or whatever you're diluting stock.

GASPARINO: Right. OK. So then why did they increase the price target?

FRANCIS: I think they're pumping up a customer is Charlie's accusation.

LEVY: This is why - this is why .

GASPARINO: Then why .

(CROSSTALK)

LEVY: Charlie, wait, wait, listen to me. Would you listen to me for a second?

FRANCIS: Talk.

LEVY: OK, here's the deal. You've got - you're doubling volume. This gigafactory is going to double the potential volume. It changes the whole case. If you read the report from Morgan Stanley they changed their base case. These guys can't make up numbers. And if the numbers suck that bad, if the numbers suck that bad, they couldn't get one percent yields on their debt.

GASPARINO: He just made my point. Diluting..

FRANCIS: He did sort of make the point.

GASPARINO: They're diluting the shareholder and they are saying .

FRANCIS: And yet, they are till raising the price target.

GASPARINO: They are not raising it. They doubled it.

FRANCIS: They doubled it.

GASPARINO: And this is insane.

FRANCIS: Jared, you are kind of making his case .

GASPARINO: And here's the other thing.

FRANCIS: That even worse bet.

GASPARINO: Here's the other thing. Yes, they do get on the phone and talk to the bankers and they do talk to the company. And someone says this is our customer. Yeah, that all does happen. Just - let the viewer know that out there.

FRANCIS: Jared?

LEVY: Yeah. It happens, Charlie, but again --

GASPARINO: OK. Thank you, you made my point again.

(CROSSTALK)

LEVY: You cannot listen to me. You cannot make up numbers.

GASPARINO: I'm trying, dude.

LEVY: You can't - There is a fair market out there, Charlie. And it's all like I could say, oh, yeah .

GASPARINO: Bear market.

LEVY: Buy this .

GASPARINO: Because we could call these guys .

LEVY: For $2 million, because you're my buddy. Buy this old Fiat from 1974, pay 2 million because it's worth it. You wouldn't do that because you've got clients to represent. You've got clients to report to. They can't just make up numbers.

GASPARINO: So, you're telling me - you're telling me - you're telling me it's beyond Morgan Stanley with the biggest retail brokerage network in the world, in America, 18,000 brokers, to pump up a client? You are saying that?

LEVY: I am 100 percent saying that.

GASPARINO: The Brooklyn Bridge is for sale, dude.

LEVY: And JPMorgan.

GASPARINO: The Brooklyn Bridge is for sale.

(CROSSTALK)

GASPARINO: The Brooklyn Bridge is for sale.

FRANCIS: All right. I think I hear a whistle.

(WHISTLE)

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Thank you, gentlemen. All right.

GASPARINO: Thanks, Jared.

FRANCIS: Thanks so much.

Coming up, two governor exclusives. First, Florida's big push to be the new hot spot for the tech industry. Governor Rick Scott tells us about how he is successfully bringing jobs down to the Sunshine state. And later, Mississippi governor Phil Bryant on his state's plan to create jobs. Is the key, fracking regulations? We're going to get the inside scoop, more "MONEY" coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Significant economic turnaround is underway in Florida where private sector job creation is booming. Especially in the tech industry. The sunshine state becoming a hotbed for innovation and businesses are taking notice. Moving their operations down south and creating nearly half a million new jobs. Since Governor Rick Scott took office in 2010. I spoke to him just a short time ago in a Fox Business exclusive.

(on camera): Thank you so much for coming on the program.

GOV. RICK SCOTT (R) FLORIDA: Well, tell me, is it true, did you all go to Roger Ailes (ph) and say, look, we need to move to Florida? We like the fact there is no income tax, better weather, close to Latin America.

FRANCIS: You're speaking my language. Singing my song, speaking my language. Yes. I love that idea. We would move to Florida in a heartbeat. Tell me, you're doing incredible things in your state that would make other states very envious. I'm looking at Amazon moving to Tampa, bringing more than 1,000 jobs with it. 300 million in capital. Time Warner moving to Tampa, with 500 new jobs. $5 million in capital investment. What did you have to offer them to get that done?

SCOTT: You know, we're a great state. No income tax and we're a right-to- work state. The gateway to Latin America. We have 5 million multilingual speakers. We have great universities, have brand new - brand new universities that are just doing science technology, engineering and math. So, we're talking to companies every day and they are clearly moving. And people are moving here, but companies are expanding. Yesterday I was with a technology company that is adding over 100 jobs just in technology. But even the non-technology companies are moving here because of our technology. Hertz, 700 jobs. Average income, $100,000. People want to be here.

FRANCIS: They do, but you're doing something different recently because Florida has had those tremendous assets for a while, yet, when you took office the unemployment rate was 11.4 percent. It is now down to 6.2. So all those things have been in place.

SCOTT: You're right, we've changed.

FRANCIS: Yeah, what have you changed recently because other states should follow your example I would think?

SCOTT: In the four years before I came into office, the state lost 832,000 jobs. Unemployment went from 3.5 to 11.1 percent. So, right after I got elected I sat down with site selectors from around the country and said here is why you should come to Florida. And they said, you know, we don't talk to Florida.

FRANCIS: Why?

SCOTT: And that has completely changed. We're talking to them now and saying what do your clients need?

FRANCIS: But why? What was the reason? Why did they say they didn't talk to Florida before?

SCOTT: Well, they said that last administration wouldn't return their phone calls. Wasn't focused, took forever, if you were even interested in making a decision. So I sat down with them. I said, here's my cell number. Call me directly. I will solve every problem I can. Plus, in the meantime, we've cut taxes 24 times in three years. This year we'll cut taxes $500 million. I've cut about 3,000 regulations. We've streamlined the permitting process. And we just do what I did in business.

FRANCIS: Jacksonville, for example, becoming a big hub for startups.

SCOTT: Yeah.

FRANCIS: In 2013 there was a big crowd funding event that drew 130,000 attendees. 20 percent came from out-of-state. Is Jacksonville the next big tech center, the same way that we have heard about Austin and, of course, we know about Silicon Valley and we are hearing about places in the Midwest? Is Jacksonville really hot?

SCOTT: Jacksonville is hot. But you know, Gainesville, Orlando, Tampa. We're going to have - I think the biggest Hispanic technology conference ever in the world is going to be in Miami in May. So people want to be here. We've got great young people. We've got great universities, great state colleges. They want to be here to build their companies. We already have the third most number of technology companies in the country in Florida. So we are the next, the whole state is the next Silicon Valley.

FRANCIS: Is it essential to be tech focused? I mean I keep hearing you say that you have I.T. professionals that are trained. If another state is watching this and wanting to follow in your footsteps, is it essential that you have that tech component and the tech training?

SCOTT: Oh, I think it is very important. But what I'm working on is to make sure universities and state colleges are graduating the students for the future. Where are all the jobs going, that's the degrees we're going to focus on and then continue to recruit companies that are already here to expand? Make sure they stay here.

FRANCIS: Yes.

SCOTT: Because other governors are trying to recruit like I am. We're just going to try to do it better than anyone else.

FRANCIS: You've got me convinced. I'm ready to open the Fox Business bureau right on the beach. I can't wait .

(CROSSTALK)

SCOTT: You would love it.

FRANCIS: Yes.

SCOTT: All right, have a great day.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: All right. We want to show you some headlines that are crossing right now from "The Wall Street Journal." Quizno's, you see it on so many corners, preparing to file for bankruptcy. The general reporting they have a $570 million debt load right now. One thing really interesting about the story, their list of creditors, some of the biggest names in private money. Avenue, Fortress, and Oak Tree, are among the folks that they owe money to right now, going into bankruptcy.

All right, up next, babies are a big business. And of course, there is an app for that. A new app claiming it is the answer for anyone trying to get pregnant or not! Also trying not to get pregnant, similarly important. Let me tell you. The CEO of Kindara is here. And we all want to retire someday, but a new survey says, it is still out of reach for many. We have got some of the worst-case scenario situations and more importantly, the way to fix them to make sure you're set no matter what!

Do you ever have too much money?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: No false-positives about it, an innovative new app is helping thousands of women get pregnant or not get pregnant. Also, very important. It's in the spotlight for innovation today. Here now with the cofounder and the CEO of Kindara, Will Sacks. Will, I can't wait to hear how this works. How does an app help you get pregnant? I mean is it just a naked picture of a really attractive person or how does it work?

WILL SACKS, KINDARA COFOUNDER & CEO: No, we haven't integrated that yet.

FRANCIS: No.

SACKS: But so, Kindara is based on data tracking. So, similarly, you know, people have heard of apps to track their weight, to track what they eat. And Kindara is an app based on tracking their personal data related to your fertility. So, women use it be entering their personal fertility signs every day. And then we analyze those signs to give them a very accurate and detailed picture of what is happening with their fertility every single day of their cycle.

FRANCIS: Wow, it sounds like there is a lot of liability in there if your app messes up really in either direction. Do you worry about that at all?

SACKS: We have good lawyers, first of all. FRANCIS: That is fantastic. That is always very important.

SACKS: Which is important and we don't worry about it too much on the pregnancy side. The worst-case scenario is the woman, it takes her longer to get pregnant. So that is not a big deal for us.

FRANCIS: Not for you. It might be for her though.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Go ahead. Keep going. Sorry, I'm trying to --

SACKS: Right. It might take her an extra few cycles, you know. And then on the birth control side we don't provide prediction to each individual woman. It's up to her to interpret her own data. So, that is how we make sure that we're not giving people bad data and they are getting a maximum understanding of their bodies every day.

FRANCIS: You have more than 55,000 monthly users. The users are reporting nearly 500 pregnancies a week. That sounds scary and dangerous. The app has helped 10,000 women get pregnant in the last year. How do you monetize that? Are you charging them?

SACKS: We're not right now. We're really focused on growth, currently. We see a lot of opportunity in the future to use people's individual situation, to connect them with products and services and practitioners who are going to help them meet their goals. So a woman who is trying to get pregnant, we can help her maybe identify a hormone problem and then connect her with a practitioner or a product that's going to help her with that problem.

FRANCIS: So, how do you see monetizing this down the road? Is it a fee- for-service? Or are you, you know, letting folks, diapers.com advertise to these folks? Or how do you see making money? Because the show is called "MONEY" and we love money.

SACKS: Yes, so the two main things that we're thinking about, are first the practitioner directory to connect women with relevant practitioners in their area.

FRANCIS: OK.

SACKS: We make money on that referral fee. And second, advice, like the mint.com for fertility. So we can connect women with products and services that are going to help them as they go through their journey to conceive.

FRANCIS: Do you - real quick - do you see other applications for this beyond pregnancy? Are there other things that you want to do?

SACKS: Yes. We see ourselves as a full women's health platform. So, right now we're really focused on fertility and pregnancy. And in the future we'll focus on other women's health challenges like breast feeding and ovulation and even menopause.

FRANCIS: Will, thanks so much. Appreciate it. Good luck to you.

SACKS: Yes, thanks, Melissa.

FRANCIS: All right, I want to show you two stocks right now. Let me show you the AMC first. It is higher after a big jump in quarterly revenue reported there on the back of "Walking Dead." And you can see they are - those investors liking that result. Up about 6.5 percent. I'd like to show you TiVo as well, the stock has been soaring. It beat its revenue estimates. Expects to benefit from the ComcastTime Warner deal. And you could see there that stock also great day for those investors. Up about 6.4 percent on the day.

So, this is so cool. I just have to show it to you. I've been fascinated with this all day. Boeing's new Black phone. It may look like an ordinary cell phone. It could really be something out of the spy movie. The Black phone not only encrypts all of your calls, it also self-destructs if anyone tries to crack it open. The secretive cell also works on multiple frequency bands and networks to make it even harder to hack into. It is so secretive in fact, that Boeing has not even provided a price or release date. It is 36 months in the making. Hopefully they will release it soon. So far investors on board with the Boeing Black. The stock is up a little more than one and a half percent on the day. I like that. I don't have any secrets, but I want the phony anyway because it is just cool.

All right, next up, more on the Icahn-eBay saga. A new round of accusations against the legendary activist investor, this time from eBay's founder and chairman. What is next? Tweet me. And tell me what you think it is today's "Money Talker."

And who is making money today? Hollywood's star's career has defied "Gravity" and has been taking off three decades ago. She is seeing her biggest pay day yet. That is so obvious. "Piles of Money" for her, though, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Shares of the Best Buy on the move right now. The company beats profit expectations. David Strasser is an analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott. David, you're on a conference call this morning. What did you hear that surprise you?

DAVID STRASSER: Well, I think they are focused. You know, 18 months ago this company everyone thought was going out of business, because the Amazon was going to put them out of business.

FRANCIS: Right.

STRASSER: I would actually argue today. They are probably one of the best brick and click, or you know, hybrid models out there that the investments they've made, the ones that they're working on, are making them very tough to compete with online.

FRANCIS: Interesting. Do you think they'll have to downsize their retail stores even more, though?

STRASSER: I mean I think so. I mean, no, they have markets where they have probably more density of stores than they need and I think over time it is inevitable that will happen. I mean they are taking hours out of the store to some degree, because, you know, 12.5 percent of their business, you know, is now online. I mean some of that productivity you just don't need as much investment in NSGA.

FRANCIS: You know, you = we're looking at the chart, though. It looks very negative, the stock fell off a cliff here. But you sound really positive. Do you think there is an opportunity?

STRASSER: Yeah, there is an opportunity here. I mean I think the proof of concept still is going to come in queue four. You know, they are at a tough queue four. Even though they beat today, they had lowered numbers due to a very promotable holiday. You know, but I think as you look at everybody who has worked in retail over the last couple of weeks I don't think anybody had a very good holiday and they are, you know, it's clearly not something specific to them. I mean there are some pluses and minuses to their business right here.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

STRASSER: This business - the stock, I think goes higher from here but ultimately you need a good Q 4 for it to really have a big move.

FRANCIS: David Strasser, thanks so much for taking time out for us. We appreciate it. Back to work.

STRASSER: All right.

FRANCIS: You're like thanks a lot. All right, Carl Icahn throwing yet another punch in his very public battle with eBay. The billionaire investor firing off his third letter to shareholders this week, he is behind the typewriter, you know, sending his letters out, furious, riling everyone up. The ecommerce giant isn't backing down, the founder and chairman himself just responded so who's going to win this fight? Here for the "Money Talker" is A.J. Capital Hilary Cramer. We have Tuttle Wealth Management's Matthew Tuttle. And the "Wall Street Journal's" James Freeman. Icahn is on fire. Once again, is he right or is he a giant pain in the ass? What do you think, Matthew?

MATTHEW TUTTLE, TUTTLE WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Well, it depends where you are sitting. If you an eBay shareholder he's brought up a lot of questions that you want definite answers to, and, you know, it is no secret that boards of directors are often going to do things that in their own best interest and not looking up for the shareholder.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

TUTTLE: So .

JAMES FREEMAN, WALL STREET JOURNAL: He might be both, to answer your questions. I mean and shareholders have definitely been enjoying the ride last month or so, since his interest has come out. But some of his tactics - it is hard to take him seriously. He starts out saying you'd got to split eBay from PayPal. That doesn't really catch on, so then he says, basically these letters saying the board needs to be taken out.

FRANCIS: You know, having cook on the board will pay pal while they are planning PayPal's features a kin to having Pete Carroll, coach of the Seahawks, sitting in when the Denver Broncos were constructing their game plan for the Super Bowl, but then again, maybe he did.

Carl Icahn is about intimidation. Corporate raider who started in the 1980s. He is the man who brought TWA down, that he made money and thousands of people without a pension. The good news is this isn't going to happen to e-bay. Either, e-bay and PayPal will stay together or they will split apart.

HILARY KRAMER, A&G CAPITAL: In my opinion, e-bay and PayPal need to stay together. And because there is synergy there as PayPal continues to grow - -

FRANCIS: But I wonder about Icahn does. I mean, if you look what he did with Apple, you know, he gets in. He has a plan. He wants apple, you know, to relieve all of this cash. He brought the shares up. He didn't achieve what he wanted that made money. It was the same thing with the debt. Something doesn't --

MATTHEW TUTTLE, CEO, TUTTLE TACTICAL MANAGEMENT: It depends on where you are. If you are an e-bay shareholder, you sitting there and cheering him on. I mean, it is up to an up percent last time I looked today. And if you read --

FRANCIS: Is he enacted as investor doing the right thing for shareholders?

KRAMER: He does the right thing --

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Putting pressure on corporate boards making sure business is run in the best way possible. The back of the day's board, it is fact challenge. This is not a journalistic explanation of what happened. You look at -- you read his case on the sale of Skype and you think there's something criminal, you learn later while the big winner actually was in resale more silver lake, and saying that the stock value was here and then 18 months later it was here and that some kind of scandal. I mean, stocks fluctuate. Investor sentiment changes and his attack is questionable but as far as shareholders, people like him buying pressure on management. So a lot of times, yes.

FRANCIS: Can it be disruptive for the company, though? I mean, it is good for shareholders. Is it bad?

(CROSSTALK)

TUTTLE: It is not going to be disruptive for the company. It makes the board of directors mad. But it is not going to effect.

KRAMER: It is going to make the lawyers richer. And I think there is distraction going on. E-bay shares will go higher. But e-bay share is going higher because the market is going higher in March. We are going to have a nice bull market, the month of March, and companies are heading --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: And we need to change the name activist investor. I mean, activist investor makes him sound like, you know, a puritanical things where he is out there.

(CROSSTALK)

KRAMER: That is what he was and now he just annoys me.

FREEMAN: I would be more confident if he is taking on a very old company, you know, horrible -- hardly managed, bloated cash, struggling pension plan that can't be sustained. This is a fairly young company, a fairly dynamic. I mean, he may be right here. I am not saying he is not, but I think it is harder call for investors than when he is taking on sort of the obvious reason --

FRANCIS: Well, maybe the stock of those companies doesn't move as readily. Maybe he is targeting companies where the stock has more beta.

TUTTLE: Well, also, I mean, e-bay shares didn't do that well last year when the market went up. So, if I am an e-bay shareholder, I look at what happened last year. I am not too happy. So, I am cheering him on if he can make this thing --.

FRANCIS: Go, Carl!

All right, thanks guys.

Up next, another governor exclusive, Mississippi's Phil Bryant lays out how he is beefing up the job market in his state. He lays out his secrets of success because at the end the date is all about money, just as Carl Icahn.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: I am Cheryl Casone with your FOX business brief.

General Motors could be fined $35 million federal safety regulators determined. The GM failed to act quickly enough to recall 1.6 million cars with faulty ignition switches. Earlier this week, GM doubled the number of recalled cars, but document show that automaker knew about the problem as early as 2004. The case is link to 33 accidents and 13 deaths.

Wells Fargo having 700 mortgage jobs across the country. Wells Fargo has cut 6900 mortgage workers since July.

And McDonald's in spending in build your own burger test, the fast-food giant launched to concept of single California location offer a tablets customers can use deflector bun, patty, cheese and toppings choices. McDonald says the move is bringing in new customers and more than a tropic (ph).

Well, that is the latest from the FOX Business Network giving you the power to prosper. "Money" will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: From the U.S. to every corner of the globe, money has been flying the around the world today starting in Switzerland where lawmakers are trying to convince the public that a minimum wage would hurt jobs and the economy. Swiss voters will vote on a proposal to impose minimum wage of $25 an hour. If it happens it would be the highest minimum wage in the world. Yes, it would. Several local economists are issuing stark warnings to Swiss citizens that you could lead to job cuts and hurt smaller companies.

All right over to Haiti, a local android tablet maker ramping up production on hot demand. Surtab started in the capital of Port-Au-Prince with an initial run of 4,000 devices. That is now being increased to 7,000 tablets a month. The Surtab looks similar to the ipad mini, it is a coincidence I'm sure. But it is just a fraction of the price. The cheapest model is $100. It is a symbol of what the island nation can achieve as it continues to recover from the devastating earthquake back in 2010. Good for them.

And landing in Malaysia, which is pushing new rules on hotels and resorts to become more appealing to Muslim tourists, Islamic tourism is now $125 billion industry. And the Malaysian government wants hotels to stop serving alcohol. Wait a minute, what? In offset, it is crazy. And offer food and facilities that comply with religious guidelines. I'm not sure about this. Muslim visitors to Malaysia have already tripled in the past decade. It is expected to grow more than 50 percent in the next six years.

All right, two hot topics right now, building a better economy and job creation. Our next guest has shown success in both areas adding 10,000 jobs and lowering unemployment by more than two points in just two years.

Joining me now on the FOX Business exclusive is Mississippi governor, Phil Bryant.

Governor, thank you so much joining us on the show.

GOV. PHIL BRYANT, MISSISSIPPI: It is always delightful to be here. Thank you for having me.

FRANCIS: Everyone in your state is a buzz thinking this will be the year of the Tuscaloosa Marine shale. This is a tremendous geological formation, EnCana Corporation and Goodrich are both planning of spending hundreds of millions of dollars to get in there. Is this the year for that shale formation?

BRYANT: Absolutely. If you look at the companies that I hear you talked about, EnCana, Goodrich is here, almost half a billion dollars worth of investment just now, about 22,000 people in the state of Mississippi employed in the oil and gas industry. It is blooming in Mississippi. Our Tuscaloosa Marine Shale is something we are counting on. We put a lot of investment in it. I cut taxes on that region for oil that is produced by hydraulic fracturing and that has stimulated the growth in that area. That and our stability to help regulate, if you will, that industry on the state level, our state's first initiative that are working hard without GCC (ph) as chairman of the interstate oil and gas compact commission, that is critical along with permitting speed. We are second in the nation.

FRANCIS: Yes. I mean, are you receiving any push back from environmentalists? Because I know your neighbors over in Louisiana had a recent oil spill. People get very nervous about fracking. I mean, that is unrelated but it gets environmentalists up in arms and people who care about the land. Are you getting any push back?

BRYANT: Well, it certain, we always do. We had the largest spill in America's history. If you look at what happened with the BP spill a few years ago, we were able to manage that. If you look at what happened in Louisiana, no loss of marine life, no injuries occurred there. These are going to occur in any type of industry. The important part of it is having an immediate response to let everyone in Washington know we care more about our land, our water, our environment than they do and we are here to protect it and the same time grow our energy.

FRANCIS: Great point.

You look at places like California, where there are need of revenue and jobs. They have the Monterey Shale which they are pretty much ignoring, you know, that they don't want to disturb. Can you quantify for you what the Tuscaloosa Marine Shale means to you? How many jobs, how many dollars, what do you see down a road?

BRYANT: Sure. I think it made in this meeting as 9,000 new jobs. I think it means billions of dollars of investment. I think it means new infrastructure, Mississippians is coming home that are now working in North Dakota and Oklahoma and perhaps Texas. And so, those Mississippians are working there because our jobs in the energy industry there, we want them to come back to Mississippi and take jobs we are creating here in the oil and gas industry.

FRANCIS: And what do you have to do to provide the right employees in the right labor force? Because I covered energy for a really long time and it was always hard to find the best engineers and the best skilled folks. What are you doing to provide the industry with that?

BRYANT: Well, of course, as workforce is trying, working with community colleges. We put several million dollars in to work for safety training facilities at one of our community colleges in southwest Mississippi. Working with Mississippi State to get petroleum engineering program back up and running. That went out of existence in the 1980s when everyone was saying that gas and liquid is out of business and we have to depend on other forms of energy. And now that it is back, we are having to restart, if you will, some of that. But we do that in a very rapid manner as a sense of urgency of getting the work force ready.

FRANCIS: Right.

Governor, thanks so much for coming on and good luck to you. I can't wait to hear about the progress.

BRYANT: Thank you so much for having me. We will talk more about it.

FRANCIS: Counting down to the last hour trading right now.

Liz Claman, what do you got coming up on the closing bell, another jammed- pack show?

LIZ CLAMAN, FBN HOST, COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL: Yes, always. Always because is that last and all-important hour.

Listen. There is a stock that is falling about nine percent today. But you need to perhaps put that aside because it is up more than 100 percent over the past year and that is neutral system. On this very day, word is announced that the Obama administration will change the labels on food to make the calories a lot bigger so we can really see what we are eating.

Dawn Zier is joining us. She has turned this company around since 2012. Again, the stock is up exponentially. There's a big short position on it but there is a lot on short position on whitewater's, its competitor as well, but it has not kept pace with new Nuetra (ph) system. Dawn is going to talk about what she makes of the new labeling that is expected to be announced tomorrow with the first lady Michelle Obama.

We are also going to be talking to the first lady of NASCAR driving, Danica Patrick, in a FOX Business exclusive. You know she has been working with go daddy for years. Go Daddy, the Web site operator. But listen, they are now trying to inspire people to start small businesses. Wait till you see the latest, I can call it nothing, Melissa, but shtick. We will show you the most incredible clip, sounds like reality TV, five people who have been paid to quit their jobs and start their own business about to make their pitch while she drives the track at 150 miles an hour.

FRANCIS: They are great ad shtick. No one does it like them. I can't wait to see that. I love Danica Patrick.

Liz, great show. I can't wait.

All right, coming up, just think of the first lady. We were just talking about this. She wants us all in shaped. That means new sweeping changes could be coming to a food label near you. Companies will add extra nutritionally information on their packaging, some say it will hurt the bottom line big time.

We will check it out because you never have too much "Money" and I think too much information.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: All right, I want to show you shares of GAP because investors there, really sitting on their hands as they wait for earnings to come out "after the bell." They announced last week that they would raise the minimum hourly wage to $9 in 2014 and then up to $10 in 2015. A lot of people think Banana Republic might be showing some improvement. So we will find out about that "after the bell." Look at that. Yu can see the stock there has been doing better of late and there are experiences as well.

All right, it is time for a little "Spare Change" if you like to spend those extra nickels and dimes on snack food, that is, you may be in for some big changes. The White House is proposing new requirements for nutrition labels that could affect every single packaged food product that you buy.

Rich Edson is on the story in D.C.

Rich, I thought these labels, it sort of blast you with the calories. They want to make sure you know exactly what you are getting into.

RICH EDSON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Right. And you know, and it is not just the size of the calorie count but the number, the actual number is probably going to be bigger. You think of it this way. So you know, let's say you pick up a cookie package and you see 100 calories on that back and that is not bad. Then you see the serving size as like half a cookie. Well, what the FDA says, you know, is that they will update serving size requirements to reflect the amounts that people actually eat. So you are going to see that. It will be more prominently displayed in the number will be larger. Then on top of that, they are also going to break out added sugars. People say that basically you want to know naturally assuring sugar but also the amount of sugar that is added into a product and a few other changes.

FRANCIS: We are looking at the label side by side and you can see the calorie counters is just a whole lot bigger. How do food producers feel about this? I mean, obviously, they have to go through the cost in designing a new label, right? How do they feel about it?

EDSON: Right. When you talk to analysts about this one and they say that the label cost, it will be an additional cost but I don't think that is necessarily the problem. They say that when you are going forward on all of this and you look it where food trends have been in the U.S. for the last four years since 2010, there have been and you will declines in American buying habits. They are moving away from processed prepackaged foods moving more toward healthier foods.

So if you have a situation where calorie count numbers are starting to move up because of serving sizes have changed that may change the way people buy these foods and could hurt the process food makers.

FRANCIS: Yes. I guess although, I mean, it is just more information. I feel like it is the same thing like when the restaurants here in New York, Dunkin Donuts, you know, when they had to put up the calories for everything thing. They thought it would drive Dunkin out of business. And instead, you just learned that the brand muffin was the most fattening thing you could possibly have, you might as well have a donut because it led. It hasn't been that terrible so, we will see.

Anyway, Rich, thanks so much. Appreciate it.

EDSON: Thanks.

FRANCIS: Up next, what is the worst thing you can imagine happening to your retirement? The average 401(k) account plummeted by 25 percent during the last financial crisis, meaning there are a lot of people out there with some catching up to do. Small-businesses are also feeling this week. We have some real-life fixes to some of the biggest problems facing your golden years. We are going to fix it. You can never have too much money.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it's on Wall Street or Main Street, here's who's making money today.

Anyone with a stake in sears? The struggling department store posting declining sales due to a quote "tough and terrible holiday corner," that's crop. But a plan to raise a billion in cash by going out to (INAUDIBLE) has investors reacting possibly, at least shares are up nearly six percent right now. The CEO Eddie Lanford (ph) is benefiting nicely. The billionaire hedge fund manager has more than 25 million shares meaning he just made an extra $57 million, because he needed it.

Also making money, miss congeniality herself, Sandra Bullock. The Hollywood actress earning tens of millions of dollars for her role in the award-winning movie "Gravity." Word is Bullock has deal included $20 million up front and that after that she gets 15 percent of Warner Brothers share of the box office revenue plus a cut from home rental and TV sales. That is already looking to be about $50 million. Wow. Means the Oscar winner is lining up for a $70 million payday. Truly out of this world! Good for her.

Making even more money than that, top executives at private equity firm Carlyle Group, the three founders each received around $93 million in dividend and salary last year. That is up 60 percent from the year before. It reflects how well the group has been doing lately. Income rose more than 20 percent last year. And its fourth quarter earnings more than tripled. Nice job.

All right, one thing almost everyone can agree on, retirement saving is a tricky thing. Ups and downs in the market, housing bubbles, unexpected expenses, there is a way to fix those worst case scenarios, so listen up.

Brian Graft is the CEO and director of the American society of pension professionals and actuaries. Thanks so much for joining us.

Let's get right to it. Let me hit you with one of the first problems. This is a high-tech business owner, the small owner, although I know, someone in this situation right now. The small business is doing well, they don't have a lot of employees, but they offer the employees a 401(k). There are new tax rules out there that, basically, double tax this distribution. So it may make it go away. How do you deal with that situation, how do you help your employees to save for retirement? What do you do?

BRIAN GRAFT, CEO, DIRECTOR, THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF PENSION PROFESSIONALS AND ACTUARIES: Well, Melissa, it's a perfectly -- it is a real problem out there with this proposal by Chairman Camp that was introduced yesterday that he would actually double tax contributions on behalf of small business owners. So the concern is if from the small business owner, it started to have doubled tax. They no longer have an incentive to keep that plans going --

FRANCIS: Right. So what should they do?

GRAFT: So what we've got to do is, one, make sure that this double tax proposal doesn't get enacted and proposals like that. Instead, what we need to be doing is encouraging more small business owners to have plans like your friend because the key to retirement for workers is having a plan at work. People making between $30,000 and $50,000, when they're covered by a plan at work, 70 percent of them participate. When they don't have a plan at work, less than five percent on them save on their own.

FRANCIS: Absolutely. Let's get on the second scenario, public schoolteacher. The problem is that this person has just gotten through putting their kids through college.

GRAFT: Right.

FRANCIS: And, basically, was using all their retirement savings for this. There are lots of people in this situation.

GRAFT: Right. Millions, actually.

FRANCIS: So now they want to try and catch up. How do you start catching up?

GRAFT: Well, the key is to kind of make sure that you're thinking about this in advance, but a critical part of the law today is the allowance of catch-up contributions. They're very important because there are a lot of people who are putting their kids through college, and then all of a sudden -- hopefully if all things go well, kids go through college. They can now catch up with respect to their retirement savings. Unfortunately, another proposal introduced yesterday would freeze benefit limits and contribution limits at current levels for over a decade.

FRANCIS: I know. But rather than talking about laws that may or may not be enacted, how do you help the person catch up? What's the first thing you would ask them to do?

GRAFT: Well, what they've got to do is plan for the catch-up scenario. So they know they've got a burden in terms of costs and expenses while the kids are going through college. They need to know that because the law allows them to put more money aside, they have an opportunity to do so. So they're going to go ahead and take that into account.

And fortunately, and millions of Americans actually do this, they then increase their contributions as they get closer to retirement so they can catch up with respect o the savings that they missed while the kids were away in college.

FRANCIS: OK. Brian, thanks so much. We appreciate your time.

GRAFT: You're welcome.

FRANCIS: All right, that's all we have more you. I hope that you are making money today. Be sure to tune in tomorrow. Thank you for joining us here at our new time. I hope you'll stay with us, 2 p.m. here on the east coast. The "Countdown to the Closing bell" starts right now with Liz Claman.

END

urn:contentItem:5BMN-SV61-JD2T-F1RV-00000-00Analysis of Current Stock Market; Discussion about Tesla in the Stock Market; Governor Rick Scott on His Success in Making Florida Business2014-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:31ZLexisNexisAnalysis of Current Stock Market; Discussion about Tesla in the Stock Market; Governor Rick Scott on His Success in Making Florida Business

MELISA FRANCIS, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: We do have a big show today. We have two governors, both exclusive, Florida's Rick Scott, Mississippi's Phil Bryant, both on huge job pushes right now. Today's signature Wall Street throwdown features Charlie Gasparino and Chapwood Fund's Jared Levy. That's going to be great, fighting over whether something smells fishy in the Tesla bond deal being underwritten by Morgan Stanley. You might want to get some popcorn for that one. And of course, there is today's "Money Talker", the latest round in Icahn versus eBay. Because even when they say it's not it is always about money.

FRANCIS: New Fed chair Janet Yellen just wrapping up her testimony before the Senate banking committee. Let's check in with Scott Shellady on the floor of the CME. You know, one thing in particular caught my attention. She said the economic data, particularly consumer spending had softened since she testified before the House committee. That was just two weeks ago! Things have gotten worse in the past two weeks, does that make you nervous, Scott?

SCOTT SHELLADY, TREAN GROUP SENIOR V.P.: Well, you know what? It is not making me nervous because I think I've felt this way for two or three months now ever since the retailers gone to came in weak over Christmas. So, here is where we sit. We've got a Fed that is going to be trying to taper. And they're tapering because - not because the economy can handle it. We're actually in a soft patch right now. But they are going to taper because it is a failed economic policy. And if they stop the taper I think that also sends another bad signal and the market could actually tumble from there as well, because, though, that reads into the fact that maybe the Fed sees something that is worse than we actually think. So we're in a very precarious spot right now.

FRANCIS: So what do you think she should do?

SHELLADY: Well, this is what I think is going to happen. I think that we try to put Q.E. out of there to inflate our way out of this problem and get some growth. We didn't buy any growth.

FRANCIS: Right.

SHELLADY: Aim two and a half percent GDP, that didn't happen, and we definitely didn't get any inflation. So, what the Fed is going to have to start doing now is fight deflation. So, I think ultimately we're going to have to stimulate, but maybe not in the way that we've been doing up until now. Maybe interest on overnight reserves or some other way because this is not going to be the way to work. I think that ultimately you're going to watch what happened in Japan. And if we do have the deflation, deflation is the one thing that the Fed is really scared about.

FRANCIS: Yeah. So, meanwhile, against that backdrop, leave that markets board up right now, look at the S&P 500. It is trading at 1853.59. All- time intraday high, 1858. We're flirting with record territory here. So, why are we seeing such a move in the S&P if you're painting a precarious picture there?

SHELLADY: Right. I know, it is perverse, is it? And why do we see the ten-year yields rally at the same time?

FRANCIS: There you go.

SHELLADY: Well, this is what's going to be. This is the world we're in. We're going to see ten percent - we're going to put ten percent on the stocks by end of the year. Maybe even 15 percent because we're going to either stimulate in a different manner, or, the economy does finally catch up and justifies these asset prices where they are. And so, those Mississippians are working there because our jobs in the energy industry there, we want them to come back to Mississippi and take jobs we are creating here in the oil and gas industry.

FRANCIS: And what do you have to do to provide the right employees in the right labor force? Because I covered energy for a really long time and it was always hard to find the best engineers and the best skilled folks. What are you doing to provide the industry with that?

BRYANT: Well, of course, as workforce is trying, working with community colleges. We put several million dollars in to work for safety training facilities at one of our community colleges in southwest Mississippi. Working with Mississippi State to get petroleum engineering program back up and running. That went out of existence in the 1980s when everyone was saying that gas and liquid is out of business and we have to depend on other forms of energy. And now that it is back, we are having to restart, if you will, some of that. But we do that in a very rapid manner as a sense of urgency of getting the work force ready.

FRANCIS: Right.

Governor, thanks so much for coming on and good luck to you. I can't wait to hear about the progress.

BRYANT: Thank you so much for having me. We will talk more about it.

FRANCIS: Counting down to the last hour trading right now.

Liz Claman, what do you got coming up on the closing bell, another jammed- pack show?

LIZ CLAMAN, FBN HOST, COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL: Yes, always. Always because is that last and all-important hour.

Listen. There is a stock that is falling about nine percent today. But you need to perhaps put that aside because it is up more than 100 percent over the past year and that is neutral system. On this very day, word is announced that the Obama administration will change the labels on food to make the calories a lot bigger so we can really see what we are eating.

Dawn Zier is joining us. She has turned this company around since 2012. Again, the stock is up exponentially. There's a big short position on it but there is a lot on short position on whitewater's, its competitor as well, but it has not kept pace with new Nuetra (ph) system. Dawn is going to talk about what she makes of the new labeling that is expected to be announced tomorrow with the first lady Michelle Obama.

We are also going to be talking to the first lady of NASCAR driving, Danica Patrick, in a FOX Business exclusive. You know she has been working with go daddy for years. Go Daddy, the Web site operator. But listen, they are now trying to inspire people to start small businesses. Wait till you see the latest, I can call it nothing, Melissa, but shtick. We will show you the most incredible clip, sounds like reality TV, five people who have been paid to quit their jobs and start their own business about to make their pitch while she drives the track at 150 miles an hour.

FRANCIS: They are great ad shtick. No one does it like them. I can't wait to see that. I love Danica Patrick.

Liz, great show. I can't wait.

All right, coming up, just think of the first lady. We were just talking about this. She wants us all in shaped. That means new sweeping changes could be coming to a food label near you. Companies will add extra nutritionally information on their packaging, some say it will hurt the bottom line big time.

We will check it out because you never have too much "Money" and I think too much information.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: All right, I want to show you shares of GAP because investors there, really sitting on their hands as they wait for earnings to come out "after the bell." They announced last week that they would raise the minimum hourly wage to $9 in 2014 and then up to $10 in 2015. A lot of people think Banana Republic might be showing some improvement. So we will find out about that "after the bell." Look at that. Yu can see the stock there has been doing better of late and there are experiences as well.

All right, it is time for a little "Spare Change" if you like to spend those extra nickels and dimes on snack food, that is, you may be in for some big changes. The White House is proposing new requirements for nutrition labels that could affect every single packaged food product that you buy.

Rich Edson is on the story in D.C.

Rich, I thought these labels, it sort of blast you with the calories. They want to make sure you know exactly what you are getting into.

RICH EDSON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Right. And you know, and it is not just the size of the calorie count but the number, the actual number is probably going to be bigger. You think of it this way. So you know, let's say you pick up a cookie package and you see 100 calories on that back and that is not bad. Then you see the serving size as like half a cookie. Well, what the FDA says, you know, is that they will update serving size requirements to reflect the amounts that people actually eat. So you are going to see that. It will be more prominently displayed in the number will be larger. Then on top of that, they are also going to break out added sugars. People say that basically you want to know naturally assuring sugar but also the amount of sugar that is added into a product and a few other changes.

FRANCIS: We are looking at the label side by side and you can see the calorie counters is just a whole lot bigger. How do food producers feel about this? I mean, obviously, they have to go through the cost in designing a new label, right? How do they feel about it?

EDSON: Right. When you talk to analysts about this one and they say that the label cost, it will be an additional cost but I don't think that is necessarily the problem. They say that when you are going forward on all of this and you look it where food trends have been in the U.S. for the last four years since 2010, there have been and you will declines in American buying habits. They are moving away from processed prepackaged foods moving more toward healthier foods.

So if you have a situation where calorie count numbers are starting to move up because of serving sizes have changed that may change the way people buy these foods and could hurt the process food makers.

FRANCIS: Yes. I guess although, I mean, it is just more information. I feel like it is the same thing like when the restaurants here in New York, Dunkin Donuts, you know, when they had to put up the calories for everything thing. They thought it would drive Dunkin out of business. And instead, you just learned that the brand muffin was the most fattening thing you could possibly have, you might as well have a donut because it led. It hasn't been that terrible so, we will see.

Anyway, Rich, thanks so much. Appreciate it.

EDSON: Thanks.

FRANCIS: Up next, what is the worst thing you can imagine happening to your retirement? The average 401(k) account plummeted by 25 percent during the last financial crisis, meaning there are a lot of people out there with some catching up to do. Small-businesses are also feeling this week. We have some real-life fixes to some of the biggest problems facing your golden years. We are going to fix it. You can never have too much money.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it's on Wall Street or Main Street, here's who's making money today.

Anyone with a stake in sears? The struggling department store posting declining sales due to a quote "tough and terrible holiday corner," that's crop. But a plan to raise a billion in cash by going out to (INAUDIBLE) has investors reacting possibly, at least shares are up nearly six percent right now. The CEO Eddie Lanford (ph) is benefiting nicely. The billionaire hedge fund manager has more than 25 million shares meaning he just made an extra $57 million, because he needed it.

Also making money, miss congeniality herself, Sandra Bullock. The Hollywood actress earning tens of millions of dollars for her role in the award-winning movie "Gravity." Word is Bullock has deal included $20 million up front and that after that she gets 15 percent of Warner Brothers share of the box office revenue plus a cut from home rental and TV sales. That is already looking to be about $50 million. Wow. Means the Oscar winner is lining up for a $70 million payday. Truly out of this world! Good for her.

Making even more money than that, top executives at private equity firm Carlyle Group, the three founders each received around $93 million in dividend and salary last year. That is up 60 percent from the year before. It reflects how well the group has been doing lately. Income rose more than 20 percent last year. And its fourth quarter earnings more than tripled. Nice job.

All right, one thing almost everyone can agree on, retirement saving is a tricky thing. Ups and downs in the market, housing bubbles, unexpected expenses, there is a way to fix those worst case scenarios, so listen up.

Brian Graft is the CEO and director of the American society of pension professionals and actuaries. Thanks so much for joining us.

Let's get right to it. Let me hit you with one of the first problems. This is a high-tech business owner, the small owner, although I know, someone in this situation right now. The small business is doing well, they don't have a lot of employees, but they offer the employees a 401(k). There are new tax rules out there that, basically, double tax this distribution. So it may make it go away. How do you deal with that situation, how do you help your employees to save for retirement? What do you do?

BRIAN GRAFT, CEO, DIRECTOR, THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF PENSION PROFESSIONALS AND ACTUARIES: Well, Melissa, it's a perfectly -- it is a real problem out there with this proposal by Chairman Camp that was introduced yesterday that he would actually double tax contributions on behalf of small business owners. So the concern is if from the small business owner, it started to have doubled tax. They no longer have an incentive to keep that plans going --

FRANCIS: Right. So what should they do?

GRAFT: So what we've got to do is, one, make sure that this double tax proposal doesn't get enacted and proposals like that. Instead, what we need to be doing is encouraging more small business owners to have plans like your friend because the key to retirement for workers is having a plan at work. People making between $30,000 and $50,000, when they're covered by a plan at work, 70 percent of them participate. When they don't have a plan at work, less than five percent on them save on their own.

FRANCIS: Absolutely. Let's get on the second scenario, public schoolteacher. The problem is that this person has just gotten through putting their kids through college.

GRAFT: Right.

FRANCIS: And, basically, was using all their retirement savings for this. There are lots of people in this situation.

GRAFT: Right. Millions, actually.

FRANCIS: So now they want to try and catch up. How do you start catching up?

GRAFT: Well, the key is to kind of make sure that you're thinking about this in advance, but a critical part of the law today is the allowance of catch-up contributions. They're very important because there are a lot of people who are putting their kids through college, and then all of a sudden -- hopefully if all things go well, kids go through college. They can now catch up with respect to their retirement savings. Unfortunately, another proposal introduced yesterday would freeze benefit limits and contribution limits at current levels for over a decade.

FRANCIS: I know. But rather than talking about laws that may or may not be enacted, how do you help the person catch up? What's the first thing you would ask them to do?

GRAFT: Well, what they've got to do is plan for the catch-up scenario. So they know they've got a burden in terms of costs and expenses while the kids are going through college. They need to know that because the law allows them to put more money aside, they have an opportunity to do so. So they're going to go ahead and take that into account.

And fortunately, and millions of Americans actually do this, they then increase their contributions as they get closer to retirement so they can catch up with respect o the savings that they missed while the kids were away in college.

FRANCIS: OK. Brian, thanks so much. We appreciate your time.

GRAFT: You're welcome.

FRANCIS: All right, that's all we have more you. I hope that you are making money today. Be sure to tune in tomorrow. Thank you for joining us here at our new time. I hope you'll stay with us, 2 p.m. here on the east coast. The "Countdown to the Closing bell" starts right now with Liz Claman.

END

urn:contentItem:5BMF-21S1-JB20-G4PB-00000-00Analysis of Current Stock Market; Discussion about Tesla in the Stock Market; Governor Rick Scott on His Success in Making Florida Business Friendly; Kindara, Application for Women's Health and Fertility Problems; Best Buy's Recent Progress2014-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:31ZLexisNexisMONEY2:00 PM ESTRick Scott, Scott Shellady, Jared Levy, Will Sacks, David Strasser, Matthew Tuttle, Jeff Freeman, Phil Bryant; Matthew Tuttle; Hilary Kramer; Brian GraftNEWSDomestic022701cb.230Analysis of Current Stock Market; Discussion about Tesla in the Stock Market; Governor Rick Scott on His Success in Making Florida Business Friendly; Kindara, Application for Women's Health and Fertility Problems; Best Buy's Recent ProgressMelissa Francis, Charlie Gasparino

MELISA FRANCIS, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: We do have a big show today. We have two governors, both exclusive, Florida's Rick Scott, Mississippi's Phil Bryant, both on huge job pushes right now. Today's signature Wall Street throwdown features Charlie Gasparino and Chapwood Fund's Jared Levy. That's going to be great, fighting over whether something smells fishy in the Tesla bond deal being underwritten by Morgan Stanley. You might want to get some popcorn for that one. And of course, there is today's "Money Talker", the latest round in Icahn versus eBay. Because even when they say it's not it is always about money.

FRANCIS: New Fed chair Janet Yellen just wrapping up her testimony before the Senate banking committee. Let's check in with Scott Shellady on the floor of the CME. You know, one thing in particular caught my attention. She said the economic data, particularly consumer spending had softened since she testified before the House committee. That was just two weeks ago! Things have gotten worse in the past two weeks, does that make you nervous, Scott?

SCOTT SHELLADY, TREAN GROUP SENIOR V.P.: Well, you know what? It is not making me nervous because I think I've felt this way for two or three months now ever since the retailers gone to came in weak over Christmas. So, here is where we sit. We've got a Fed that is going to be trying to taper. And they're tapering because - not because the economy can handle it. We're actually in a soft patch right now. But they are going to taper because it is a failed economic policy. And if they stop the taper I think that also sends another bad signal and the market could actually tumble from there as well, because, though, that reads into the fact that maybe the Fed sees something that is worse than we actually think. So we're in a very precarious spot right now.

FRANCIS: So what do you think she should do?

SHELLADY: Well, this is what I think is going to happen. I think that we try to put Q.E. out of there to inflate our way out of this problem and get some growth. We didn't buy any growth.

FRANCIS: Right.

SHELLADY: Aim two and a half percent GDP, that didn't happen, and we definitely didn't get any inflation. So, what the Fed is going to have to start doing now is fight deflation. So, I think ultimately we're going to have to stimulate, but maybe not in the way that we've been doing up until now. Maybe interest on overnight reserves or some other way because this is not going to be the way to work. I think that ultimately you're going to watch what happened in Japan. And if we do have the deflation, deflation is the one thing that the Fed is really scared about.

FRANCIS: Yeah. So, meanwhile, against that backdrop, leave that markets board up right now, look at the S&P 500. It is trading at 1853.59. All- time intraday high, 1858. We're flirting with record territory here. So, why are we seeing such a move in the S&P if you're painting a precarious picture there?

SHELLADY: Right. I know, it is perverse, is it? And why do we see the ten-year yields rally at the same time?

FRANCIS: There you go.

SHELLADY: Well, this is what's going to be. This is the world we're in. We're going to see ten percent - we're going to put ten percent on the stocks by end of the year. Maybe even 15 percent because we're going to either stimulate in a different manner, or, the economy does finally catch up and justifies these asset prices where they are. But in either scenario I think we're going to add to stocks, just because I think ultimately I think it's going to be the stimulus. I don't think it's going to be the economy is not going to catch up. And number two is that the ten-year is telling me that we still have a lot to worry about. That's why it didn't, the ten-year didn't break when we saw the stocks rally last week and early this week. Now, the ten year are starting to rally and the yields are starting to break, and we are still rallying as far as the stock market goes. We are in trouble. We need to see bunches of good numbers. Boy, oh, boy, is this jobs number on Friday, next Friday, very important.

FRANCIS: Nice setup for us, Scott, thanks so much.

SHELLADY: Already.

FRANCIS: So, everyone is talking Tesla today. Shares hitting the brinks after wild week of gains. Auto makers planning a bond offering to raise $1.6 billion for its new battery factory. But here is where the controversy comes in. So, one of the banks that is backing the deal, Morgan Stanley just released a report with a huge price target raise that sent the stock soaring. Is there a conflict of interest in there? Get ready to rumble in today's Wall Street Throwdown. It is Chapwood Investments, Jared Levy, against our very own Charlie Gasparino.

FRANCIS: Oh, yeah. There you go. The whistle .

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Charlie.

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS: You've got to do that in my ear?

FRANCIS: Yes he did have to do that, he wanted to get your attention ahead of time and ensure that it was a fair fight. What do you think? You're the one Charlie Gasparino, you're one that sort of raised the issue. Isn't that convenient? They raised .

GASPARINO: Gambling here - Is it gambling?

FRANCIS: From 153 to 320.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: And then boom it's announced the next day that they're underwriting the convert deal.

GASPARINO: Well, the one of the - one of the .

FRANCIS: One of four.

GASPARINO: I mean this is so obvious it is not even worth debating. Anybody that says it is not obvious is crazy. And just doesn't know how Wall Street works. The bottom line is this, these Wall Street firm sells - somewhere ten years after we had a major settlement in terms of Wall Street allegedly cleaning up its sell-side research, separating, creating the alleged or the infamous Chinese Wall, making it more sturdy it is just as broken. This stuff goes on every day.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Jared, Charles has just called you crazy and said you don't know how Wall Street works, by the way.

GASPARINO: One other thing, we should put out.

FRANCIS: Just not to throw .

GASPARINO: One other thing we should put out - They didn't just like, you know, say Tesla is a good company.

FRANCIS: No, 153 to 320. I mean that's .

GASPARINO: They went insane.

FRANCIS: Jared, are you crazy?

JARED LEVY, CHAPWOOD FUND MANAGING PARTNER: OK, maybe a little bit. You know, I've been doing this for 20 years, right? And I think Charlie is giving way too much credit to the four analysts that maybe just graduated from Wharton over at Morgan Stanley. Like they're calling Goldman and JPMorgan, say, hey guys, guess what? First of all, we're going to issue debt and we're going to dilute the shares. Which normally sends stock lower by the way. Just to read .

GASPARINO: Convertible debt?

LEVY: Yeah. Convertible - whatever your .

GASPARINO: It's going to convert.

LEVY: Issue debt or whatever you're diluting stock.

GASPARINO: Right. OK. So then why did they increase the price target?

FRANCIS: I think they're pumping up a customer is Charlie's accusation.

LEVY: This is why - this is why .

GASPARINO: Then why .

(CROSSTALK)

LEVY: Charlie, wait, wait, listen to me. Would you listen to me for a second?

FRANCIS: Talk.

LEVY: OK, here's the deal. You've got - you're doubling volume. This gigafactory is going to double the potential volume. It changes the whole case. If you read the report from Morgan Stanley they changed their base case. These guys can't make up numbers. And if the numbers suck that bad, if the numbers suck that bad, they couldn't get one percent yields on their debt.

GASPARINO: He just made my point. Diluting..

FRANCIS: He did sort of make the point.

GASPARINO: They're diluting the shareholder and they are saying .

FRANCIS: And yet, they are till raising the price target.

GASPARINO: They are not raising it. They doubled it.

FRANCIS: They doubled it.

GASPARINO: And this is insane.

FRANCIS: Jared, you are kind of making his case .

GASPARINO: And here's the other thing.

FRANCIS: That even worse bet.

GASPARINO: Here's the other thing. Yes, they do get on the phone and talk to the bankers and they do talk to the company. And someone says this is our customer. Yeah, that all does happen. Just - let the viewer know that out there.

FRANCIS: Jared?

LEVY: Yeah. It happens, Charlie, but again --

GASPARINO: OK. Thank you, you made my point again.

(CROSSTALK)

LEVY: You cannot listen to me. You cannot make up numbers.

GASPARINO: I'm trying, dude.

LEVY: You can't - There is a fair market out there, Charlie. And it's all like I could say, oh, yeah .

GASPARINO: Bear market.

LEVY: Buy this .

GASPARINO: Because we could call these guys .

LEVY: For $2 million, because you're my buddy. Buy this old Fiat from 1974, pay 2 million because it's worth it. You wouldn't do that because you've got clients to represent. You've got clients to report to. They can't just make up numbers.

GASPARINO: So, you're telling me - you're telling me - you're telling me it's beyond Morgan Stanley with the biggest retail brokerage network in the world, in America, 18,000 brokers, to pump up a client? You are saying that?

LEVY: I am 100 percent saying that.

GASPARINO: The Brooklyn Bridge is for sale, dude.

LEVY: And JPMorgan.

GASPARINO: The Brooklyn Bridge is for sale.

(CROSSTALK)

GASPARINO: The Brooklyn Bridge is for sale.

FRANCIS: All right. I think I hear a whistle.

(WHISTLE)

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Thank you, gentlemen. All right.

GASPARINO: Thanks, Jared.

FRANCIS: Thanks so much.

Coming up, two governor exclusives. First, Florida's big push to be the new hot spot for the tech industry. Governor Rick Scott tells us about how he is successfully bringing jobs down to the Sunshine state. And later, Mississippi governor Phil Bryant on his state's plan to create jobs. Is the key, fracking regulations? We're going to get the inside scoop, more "MONEY" coming up.

FRANCIS: Significant economic turnaround is underway in Florida where private sector job creation is booming. Especially in the tech industry. The sunshine state becoming a hotbed for innovation and businesses are taking notice. Moving their operations down south and creating nearly half a million new jobs. Since Governor Rick Scott took office in 2010. I spoke to him just a short time ago in a Fox Business exclusive.

(on camera): Thank you so much for coming on the program.

GOV. RICK SCOTT (R) FLORIDA: Well, tell me, is it true, did you all go to Roger Ailes (ph) and say, look, we need to move to Florida? We like the fact there is no income tax, better weather, close to Latin America.

FRANCIS: You're speaking my language. Singing my song, speaking my language. Yes. I love that idea. We would move to Florida in a heartbeat. Tell me, you're doing incredible things in your state that would make other states very envious. I'm looking at Amazon moving to Tampa, bringing more than 1,000 jobs with it. 300 million in capital. Time Warner moving to Tampa, with 500 new jobs. $5 million in capital investment. What did you have to offer them to get that done?

SCOTT: You know, we're a great state. No income tax and we're a right-to- work state. The gateway to Latin America. We have 5 million multilingual speakers. We have great universities, have brand new - brand new universities that are just doing science technology, engineering and math. So, we're talking to companies every day and they are clearly moving. And people are moving here, but companies are expanding. Yesterday I was with a technology company that is adding over 100 jobs just in technology. But even the non-technology companies are moving here because of our technology. Hertz, 700 jobs. Average income, $100,000. People want to be here.

FRANCIS: They do, but you're doing something different recently because Florida has had those tremendous assets for a while, yet, when you took office the unemployment rate was 11.4 percent. It is now down to 6.2. So all those things have been in place.

SCOTT: You're right, we've changed.

FRANCIS: Yeah, what have you changed recently because other states should follow your example I would think?

SCOTT: In the four years before I came into office, the state lost 832,000 jobs. Unemployment went from 3.5 to 11.1 percent. So, right after I got elected I sat down with site selectors from around the country and said here is why you should come to Florida. And they said, you know, we don't talk to Florida.

FRANCIS: Why?

SCOTT: And that has completely changed. We're talking to them now and saying what do your clients need?

FRANCIS: But why? What was the reason? Why did they say they didn't talk to Florida before?

SCOTT: Well, they said that last administration wouldn't return their phone calls. Wasn't focused, took forever, if you were even interested in making a decision. So I sat down with them. I said, here's my cell number. Call me directly. I will solve every problem I can. Plus, in the meantime, we've cut taxes 24 times in three years. This year we'll cut taxes $500 million. I've cut about 3,000 regulations. We've streamlined the permitting process. And we just do what I did in business.

FRANCIS: Jacksonville, for example, becoming a big hub for startups.

SCOTT: Yeah.

FRANCIS: In 2013 there was a big crowd funding event that drew 130,000 attendees. 20 percent came from out-of-state. Is Jacksonville the next big tech center, the same way that we have heard about Austin and, of course, we know about Silicon Valley and we are hearing about places in the Midwest? Is Jacksonville really hot?

SCOTT: Jacksonville is hot. But you know, Gainesville, Orlando, Tampa. We're going to have - I think the biggest Hispanic technology conference ever in the world is going to be in Miami in May. So people want to be here. We've got great young people. We've got great universities, great state colleges. They want to be here to build their companies. We already have the third most number of technology companies in the country in Florida. So we are the next, the whole state is the next Silicon Valley.

FRANCIS: Is it essential to be tech focused? I mean I keep hearing you say that you have I.T. professionals that are trained. If another state is watching this and wanting to follow in your footsteps, is it essential that you have that tech component and the tech training?

SCOTT: Oh, I think it is very important. But what I'm working on is to make sure universities and state colleges are graduating the students for the future. Where are all the jobs going, that's the degrees we're going to focus on and then continue to recruit companies that are already here to expand? Make sure they stay here.
